text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
calm with koji rub steak that's right
you know how they say if something
sounds too good to be true it probably
is well this experiment could have been
that because recently i saw an article
that claimed you could use koji rice to
get the same effect you get from dry
aged in a steak for like a month and a
half and since the article is from a
legit publication and they had
before-and-after pictures along with
testimonials to its effectiveness
i figured i would give this a try and
what follows is that experiment so what
they said to do is find some of this
koji rice which i found very easily
online and i really hoped i'd ordered
the right stuff because there was
absolutely no english on this package
but it did look the same as the pictures
i saw so i'm pretty sure this is the
right stuff and apparently what this is
is rice that's been inoculated with some
kind of mysterious fungus and this is
what they actually used to make soy
sauce and miso and sake and things like
that and apparently what you're supposed
to do is grind this up and then use that
to coach your steaks and for that i
decide to use this mortar and pestle in
the article that said to powder it but i
also saw that you had to scrape this off
before you fried the steaks so i thought
if i just crushed it like this it would
be easier to get off the steaks and i
still would be able to coat it so this
is actually the only change I made to
the method I read but anyway I smash
that up until I thought it was small
enough to coat my steaks and there they
are my test subjects two beautiful thick
New York strips so I proceeded to coat
my steaks all over with that crushed
Koji rice and we're calling this koji
rub steak because it sounds good but
there really wasn't a lot of rubbing
going on it was more like sprinkling and
pressing and then once I was set I
transfer those onto a rack for full air
circulation and as you can see I put a
few paper towels down on the pan because
I thought I was going to have a lot of
leakage which turned out not to be the
case and then apparently all we need to
do is put this in the fridge for two to
three days and boom a dry aged steak so
that's what I did and this is what it
looked like to in 3/4 days later and
what exactly has happened here I have
absolutely no idea I mean I couldn't
tell if that fungus was growing or that
was just the rice swelling I really
don't know but it did look pretty
similar to the pictures in the article
and it did have Iver
pleasant very distinct kind of nutty
dry-aged meat aroma and then apparently
what's supposed to happen at this point
we're supposed to scrape all that Koji
rice off the steak before seasoning and
cooking so I took the back of a knife
and scrape that Koji rice sludge off and
right here I was getting kind of excited
because it really did have the
appearance of dry aged steak which
you're going to get a pretty good look
at here so at this point I was kind of
thinking hey maybe this worked so it
kind of looked like the real thing and
it sort of smelled like the real thing
but was it going to taste like the real
thing which of course was the next test
so I cleaned that up and seasoned it
very simply with some kosher salt all
right for an experiment like this you
don't want any herbs and spices in the
way so I did just a little bit of salt
before pan frying this and some
clarified butter and one thing I
remember mentioned in the article was
that because of the Koji reaction on the
surface the meat was sear up a lot
faster and a lot browner than usual and
as I turn this over I found that to be
absolutely true that my friends is some
serious crust if ocation but I'm not
actually sure if that's the Koji or from
that surface being so nice and dry but
regardless that is a beautiful crust but
anyway I'm going to fast forward here a
little bit because this is not a how to
cook a steak video we've done those so
we're going to skip ahead to when the
steak was done at which point it looked
like this and of course I had to let it
rest before I cut in and while I was
waiting and my read my steaks glistening
beauty I did notice a fairly distinct
and quite pleasant dry aged kind of
steak aroma it really did smell good but
then again most steak seared like this
do so I let that rest almost enough time
before slicing in for the official taste
test and as I started to slice this one
thing that struck me is it felt kind of
firm like a little firmer than I would
expect so that seemed a little odd but I
was thinking maybe it's just the crust
so I cut a few slices and while maybe
slightly past medium-rare still look
very good pink and juicy and as I
mentioned had a very delicious smell to
it so so far past the eye test and the
nose test but it was finally time for
the most important test the taste test
so I cut a piece and took a bite and it
tasted very good like a good steak
should
but did it taste like a steak that was
dry-aged well the answer to that is sort
of I would say it did taste different
and possibly better than an untreated
steak is it did have that kind of nutty
subtle sweetness that a dry aged steak
will have but what I found lacking was
that kind of underlying funk that you
get from that authentic dry aged steak
which is really not an easy flavor to
describe unless you've had it so
flavor-wise I do think that Koji added
something reminiscent of a dry aged
steak but texturally not so much not
only did this treatment not make it more
tender it seemed like it may have
actually made it a little less tender in
fact I cut a few more slices off that
thicker end which was cooked a little
less but I got the same results so I was
really hoping this technique would not
only give the flavor of a dry aged steak
but would also help produce a nice
tender mouthfeel which unfortunately
really didn't happen now is that because
we went three days in not to possibly so
in conclusion can you really use Koji
rice to simulate dry aging steak I'm
really not sure because I'm not sure if
I even did this right but if I did do
this right and that's how it was
supposed to come out I would say the
answer is no I really did enjoy how this
tasted but as far as simulating a dry
aged piece of beef that takes usually
about a month and a half I would say
this two or three day coaching method
does not achieve quite the same results
so do I really hope you give this a try
soon I'm not sure to put it another way
if I had to pick an emoji to describe
the steak age with Koji it would be the
am not sure face do they have that one
I'm not even sure but I still hope you
head over to food wishes comm for all
the ingredient amounts and more info as
usual and as always enjoy
you
